newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ bonds end with soft tone after promising start.
newsitem.headline: NZ bonds end with soft tone after promising start.

text.p: Figures in brackets compare against previous day's close
FUTURES PHYSICAL YIELD (PCT)
90-DAY BILLS (JUN) 92.82 (PREV 92.86) 90-DAYS 6.85 (PREV 6.89) 3-YR BONDS (JUN) 92.45 (PREV 92.45) 02/00 7.43 (PREV 7.42)
OVERNIGHT CASH 6.05 PCT (PREV 6.00) US 5-YR 6.64 (PREV 6.55)
* NZ yields finish slightly weaker after quiet day
* Short end manages a small rally
* Mkt consensus remains for easier RBNZ stance in June
New Zealand yields gave up their small early gains to finish with a soft tone on Thursday, after what dealers said had been a quiet session.
The mid bonds, initially boosted by local buying interest and a NZ$100 million five-year eurobond issued by Sweden overnight, ended a basis point higher in yield at 7.43 percent.
The 11/06 maturity ended three basis points higher in yield at 7.70 percent after a promising start in which it virtually ignored selling in U.S. Treasuries.
Weakness in shorter dated Australian debt had not helped sentiment. That market weakened as Reserve Bank of Australia governor Ian Macfarlane ruled out a policy easing and warned about wages growth.

"The market is a little reluctant to buy actually. It looks like it might just drift off in the next day or two, particularly the long end -- that's starting to get a little nervous about what might happen in the States, and I think that's probably wise," one dealer said.
The U.S. Federal Reserve next meets on May 20 and analysts say the market seems divided over the prospects of a hike in official interests rates.
New Zealand short rates managed to finish a touch stronger, with the physical 90-day bank bills down four basis points to 6.85 percent and the front futures contract up one to 92.87.
The currency's Trade-Weighted Index ended eight basis points lower at 67.87.

Dealers said Reserve Bank of New Zealand governor Don Brash had put the brakes on the market's recent easing bias by telling a parliamentary committee on Wednesday that at this stage, the bank's assumptions for monetary conditions remained unchanged.
Brash was seen monitoring economic data until the bank's June monetary policy statement, but the market consensus still favoured an easier stance in that statement.
-- Catherine McCaw, Wellington newsroom (64 4) 471 4275
